On Tue, 01 Jun 2004 22:18:55 +0100, Colin Green <cgreen@...> wrote:
> You're right that culling stagnant species does often give rise to
> 'jumps' in a search. 

That was just one possible explanation for fitness jumps following
stagnant stretches.  There may be others.

> But do you agree that some gradual improvements
> come about by connecting to neurons that were previously not
> contributing to the fitness of a genome. This must be the case because
> as I said before ALL neurons start out like this. So really the question
> is not whether redundant structure sometimes gets incorporated, but how
> much redundant structure gets incorporated and participates in the
> search process? 

I'm not really sure that is the question.  New connections arise, but
they may be forming new connections to neurons that *were* already
doing something useful.  Not all new topological additions are linking
up redundant structures.

In biology, as far as I understand, more often than not new features
are coopted from features that already served another adaptive purpose
(this dynamic is called "exaptation").  It is widely held that
feathers first evolved for the purposes of insulation, and were later
coopted for flight.  Another hypothesis proposes that legs evolved
from lateral fins used to help fish that foraged near shores, with
dense vegetation and debris, to navigate more easily in such
environments (helping them "semi-walk" through or over dense aquatic
vegetation and push themselves along the river bottom in shallow
areas).

Rarely do organisms carry around a bunch of neutral morphology just
waiting for it to become adaptive.  That's not a very good
evolutionary strategy.

However, you bring up a good point about excess capacity in DNA, or
junk DNA.  More below...

> I don't think there is really a limit since some small sub-structure
> within a large random network may get connected too and become
> beneficial. I think this must happen in nature to some extent since DNA
> seems so abundant and seems to contain a whole load of junk (not proven
> though AFAIK, junk DNA could turn out to have a useful and direct role).
> From that you could conclude that DNA  is cheap to carry around and
> therefore nature has not much reason to keep it trimmed to a minimum,
> certainly I think I'm right in saying that there are a lot of genes in
> the human genome that are from our ancient history and are permanently
> disabled. 

Right...and this is a good point.  NEAT already employs this concept
with the notion of disabled connection genes.  But there is a *huge*
difference between carrying around a lot of disabled DNA, as opposed
to actually expressing all of that DNA in the phenotype.  One is
cheap, as you point out...the other is grossly expensive.

Our implementation of NEAT does not use disabled genes, so of course
we didn't use them in the experiments for our paper.  They might be
very important.  We won't know for sure (until somebody does the
experiments). :)

So I could be sold that "junk DNA" might be useful, perhaps extremely
so.  But the idea of a lot of neutral or slightly maladaptive
structure expressed in the phenotype, that is just waiting around to
become useful?  I'm *highly* skeptical that this is a good idea.

> >Why not start with a fair amount of junk?
> >
> Well why not indeed?  One problem here is that if you have a lot of
> connections coming into an output node then it becomes difficult, if not
> imposible for any individual deletions mutations to effect the
> functionality of the network, since you will just get a load of noise on
> the output node from all of the different connnections. But it is quite
> possible to start with genomes that have interconected hidden nodes that
> are completely self contained, or that only connect to inputs nodes. The
> search can then choose to connect into these hidden nodes selectively.
> This might actually be a good way of searching, just dump a load of
> structures from past experiments into a seed population, ensure they
> aren't connected to output nodes and you have something very similar to
> disabled genes in biological DNA.

I think the easiest way to mimic junk DNA from biology is to simply
start with a lot of random genes that are simply not expressed, and
allow them to collect up during the run.  Although, do you use
disabled genes to determine compatibility?  If so, this calculation
can be computationally expensive, and if you have extremely large
genomes that you have to compare every generation, that might be an
issue.

> Yes that's right. But that is what evolution is all about. The vast
> majority of the time it comes up with useless structures, and every once
> in a while (like every few million years or so) something novel is
> found. 

Right...but the useless structures are not generally kept around.  You
don't see organisms with lots of useless organs or appendages just
waiting to become useful.

> Apologies for the slightly longer than expected reply, hope it doesn't
> sound too much like rambling :)

No...I think it's a good discussion.

Derek
